IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To advance laws and policies to improve the lives and opportunities of people living in poverty
IRS990.MissionDesc: The Sargent Shriver National Center on Poverty Law (the Shriver Center) is an Illinois not-for-profit corporation that provides national leadership in advancing laws and policies that secure justice to improve the lives and opportunities of people living in poverty.
IRS990.Desc: The Shriver Center's Advocacy Program pursues justice for low-income people, poor communities, and communities of color. Our advocates work with community organizations, service providers, legislators, and other allies at both the federal and state level to achieve high-level, systemic policy changes that advance justice and opportunity. We lead the Legal Impact Network, a group of the strongest advocacy organizations across 32 states working to address poverty and racial inequality. We coordinate multi-state strategies to win policy and legal victories for people living in poverty.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: The Shriver Center's Advocate Resources and Training Program builds the skills and capacities of equal justice advocates, thereby increasing their impact. Our Leadership Institute equips new and emerging leaders to lead and advance social change agendas. Our Racial Justice Training Institute is a groundbreaking national leadership program rooted in a commitment to race equity as an integral and essential part of anti-poverty advocacy. Our Clearinghouse Community offers advocates a place to connect with one another and find important tools and resources to advance their work.

OtherLiabilitiesOrgGrp.Desc: Funds held on behalf of others

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The income from the endowment fund may be expended for legal services projects of the Shriver Center that embody the values and goals of Sargent Shriver.

FIN 48 Note from Audited Financial Statements The Shriver Center was granted an exemption from federal income tax by the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to the provisions of Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). The Shriver Center qualifies for the charitable contribution deduction under Section 170(b)(1)(A)(vi) and has been classified as an organization that is not a private foundation under Section 509(a)(1). The tax exempt purpose of the Shriver Center and the nature in which it operates is described above. The Shriver Center continues to operate in compliance with its tax exempt purpose. The Shriver Center's annual information and income tax returns filed with the federal and state governments are subject to examination for the past three years filed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Board of Directors has authorized the audit committee to review and approve the Form 990. A copy of the audit committee's approved Form 990 was provided to the entire Board prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: All new board members, staff and volunteers are required to complete the conflict of interest form before they begin service with the Shriver Center. The Chief Operating Officer annually distributes conflict of interest forms to board members, staff and volunteers. The Chief Operating Officer collects and reviews the completed conflict of interest forms and logs them into a database of potential conflicts which is shared with the Board and senior management and referred to during each procurement process. The conflict of interest policy is monitored periodically throughout the year.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Shriver Center has developed a target scale for each position based on market research on salaries for similar positions in the Chicago area. This target salary scale is reviewed annually by senior management during the budget process and revised as necessary. This information is also shared with the Chair of the Board, who is responsible for recommending the President's salary to the Board. The Board approves the President's salary. The process is documented in the Board minutes. The President is responsible for determining compensation for all other officers and key employees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Shriver Center posts its annual report, audited financial statements, and 990 on its own website, www.povertylaw.org. The Shriver Center Form 990, governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements are available from the Shriver Center upon request.
